We provide axioms that guarantee a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Contains images and supplementary material.)

The ability of viruses to antagonize the antiviral response of the host is a common strategy used by pathogens to propagate and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the antiviral response of the host and contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some proton channel residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The stability of global grain production is threatened by the increasing variability of growing conditions. We quantify this threat by showing that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance to maintain global food security.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level diet identification. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA sequences was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study demonstrates the power of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth and composition in large herbivore assemblages. It also provides a framework for quantifying diet overlap and its implications for coexistence

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, but they are uncertain about the length of the crisis. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but they anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem in the open ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major breakthrough in the field of synucleinopathies. The results also suggest that caspase-1 may be a promising therapeutic target in MSA and other synucleinopathies. This hypothesis is currently being tested in a clinical trial. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling vascular function and is the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform a variety of functions. The endothelium is able to integrate multiple lines of information from multiple sources to control vascular function. The communication network between endothelial cells is complex and is composed of thousands of connections between cells. The network is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. The network is also organized in a way that allows for the propagation of signals in a short distance. These properties allow for the endothelium to efficiently control vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We present a data infrastructure that provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available through an API and accompanying software packages, and are updated daily. The data are relevant to tracking the pandemic, and to augmenting traditional public health reporting. The data infrastructure is available to the public at no cost.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is poorly understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for diverse types of natural products. We also identify a number of antimicrobial peptides that could be used as therapeutics. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products and provide a resource for future discovery. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon are poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in dyadic encounters, directly influences social dominance. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward processing, in mediating the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic link between anxiety and mitochondrial dysfunction, which may be relevant to other social disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with complex shapes and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a critical component of the oxygen transport system in mammals. The Hb system is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and regulatory proteins. Here we demonstrate that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of Hb expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in adult bone marrow and is down-regulated in fetal liver. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult Hb expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. Cancer cells often have mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, which can confer resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that this resistance is mediated by SREBP1/SCD1-dependent lipogenesis, and that this resistance can be overcome by mTORC1 inhibition. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models for PI3K-mutated breast cancer and PTEN-defective prostate cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are associated with heart failure in patients. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. These findings may help to explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating hypertension. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. We found that the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. However, the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting has not yet been sufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring bird populations to evaluate the effectiveness of forest policies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our approach can be used to design new antibiotics against other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is easier to train and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. It is also easier to implement and optimize for hardware. The proposed architecture is thus a significant advance in the field of deep learning.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT highstands are observed during times of high eccentricity. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, and with adverse consequences on general health. The mechanisms underlying these effects are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

CTLA-4 is essential for immunological tolerance, but its specific function in different systemic diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that conditional deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice resulted in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. Notably, cell transfer of thymocytes de novo produced myocarditis, otherwise not observed in donor mice depleted in adulthood. Moreover, CTLA-4 deficiency affected both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a key regulator of both self-tolerance and immune responses. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We propose that horizontal transfers of genes encoding enzymes that enable efficient digestion of plant cell walls, including lignocellulose, triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. These findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the evolution of plant cell walls. (Simplified version available.)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules to improve their performance against variants. Our results provide a proof-of-concept for the use of deep learning in antibody engineering. This approach can be used to identify antibody variants that can bind to the same epitope as the original antibody and to identify mutations that can improve the binding affinity of the original antibody to the epitope. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform determines AD risk by a factor of 12. APOE2 is associated with a twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE4 is associated with a twofold increased risk. APOE is also a potent phagocytic protein in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of complement protein C1q in AD brains, suggesting that APOE4 may be more susceptible to AD because of increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be more susceptible to AD because of increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated degeneration. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 is associated with increased C1q levels in the blood of healthy individuals

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the origin of the inner core.

Marijuana abuse is a major public health problem. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]), which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most fundamental of its cognitive functions. Here, we use the most powerful artificial neural networks to make quantitative predictions about the brain’s neural responses to language. We find that these models, which are trained purely on vision, explain nearly all of the variance in the brain’s neural responses to sentences—and even better than human experts. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. They also suggest that the brain’s language machinery may be more similar to, and evolved from, visual processing than we previously thought. This may have implications for understanding the brain’s language machinery and for developing computational models of language processing.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, it is still in its infancy in scientific computing. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that many well-posed problems in scientific computing do not have algorithms that can compute stable solutions with high accuracy. We introduce a new class of algorithms that can compute stable solutions to well-posed problems in scientific computing. We also prove that only a small number of layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that can compute stable solutions to well-posed problems in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough and the inability of the public to understand exponential growth. The latter is often attributed to a classic experiment published in 1972. We show that the experiment’s design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also that the flawed results are still being used to support the conclusion that the public is unable to understand exponential growth.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae that affects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the nose. The causative agent of a third, less common form of leprosy, mycobacterium lepromatosis, is unknown. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a Mexican patient and compared it with that of M. leprae. The two genomes are similar in size and synteny, and have undergone extensive pseudogenization. M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the two leprosy bacilli than is M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides insights into the evolution of the leprosy bacilli and the mechanisms that have led to the loss of functions required for the survival of the leprosy bacilli in the human host. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the origin of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. Here, we unveil a universal mechanism for the entanglement dynamics in isolated quantum systems. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions, which allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a new perspective on the entanglement dynamics and its connection to thermodynamics. It also opens the door to the study of entanglement in open quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. In contrast, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development is described in this paper. The vaccine is based on a recoded segment of the viral spike protein, which is the viral protein most relevant for SARS-CoV-2 infection. The recoding introduces 283 silent mutations, which are not expected to affect the viral fitness. The recoding also removes the furin cleavage site within the spike protein, which is expected to improve the safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine generates high levels of spike IgG antibodies and plaque reduction neutralization titers in hamsters. The vaccine protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus, and the level of protection is comparable to that of the wild-type virus. The vaccine is expected to be suitable for mass vaccination programs. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is poorly understood. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a mechanistic model to understand historical epidemics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of the clinically approved drug, geldanamycin. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is thought to sever filaments by binding to the barbed end and to the neck region. However, the physiological relevance of this mechanism is unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to the barbed end and to the neck region, but that filament curvature favors severing. Surprisingly, tension has no effect on ADF binding, but surprisingly, it enhances severing. We propose that the ADF-induced filament torque enhances severing by 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have important implications for understanding the role of ADF in cell motility and cell division. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in reward-processing regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by insulin. Future studies are needed to determine the extent to which the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are specific to fructose or are due to its ability to increase insulin levels. Understanding the mechanisms by which fructose promotes feeding behavior may help to explain the obesogenic environment in which we live and may lead to the development of new strategies to reduce the prevalence of obesity. Madagascar is a unique island with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. The admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar and its population history. This information is essential for the conservation of the unique biodiversity of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome encounters. In addition to reading mRNA sequences, the ribosome can also read sequences in the mRNA that are not part of the protein-coding region. One of the most common modifications in mRNA coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in 10–20% of mRNA sequences. We found that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and make subtle changes to the rate of protein synthesis and the decoding of mRNA sequences. This study provides insight into how the ribosome can read sequences in mRNA that are not part of the protein-coding region. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of aquatic mammals. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes is driven by the aquatic environment and is confined to intermediate sizes.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a less efficient antiviral defense response at cool temperature. This results in higher levels of viral replication at cool temperature. Our findings have implications for understanding the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus and other respiratory viruses. They also suggest that the antiviral defense response of infected cells may contribute to the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. (PsycINFO Database Record

The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause infections in a wide range of hosts, including humans, by sensing environmental signals, such as the presence of surfaces. Here we demonstrate that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili as a mechanosensitive sensor to detect the mechanical activity of these pilus appendages. This mechanosensitive signal transduction pathway is required for the sensing of surfaces and the regulation of a wide range of virulence factors. Our findings thus provide a mechanism for P. aeruginosa to sense the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin and to respond to this signal by promoting long-term attachment to surfaces and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing may be a general mechanism for bacteria to sense their environment. Understanding the mechanisms used by bacteria to sense their environment is important for understanding how bacteria adapt to their environment and cause infections. Understanding these mechanisms may also lead to the development of new antibacterial strategies.

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global problem. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging viruses. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a more proactive “One Health” approach to obtain a better understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is essential to prevent future pandemics and to mitigate the impact of the current pandemic on wildlife and human health.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the mechanisms that lead to Aβ accumulation and the ensuing neurotoxicity are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, rather than microglia, are the major source of inflammatory factors in AD. This finding has important implications for AD pathogenesis, since it suggests that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be the primary cause of the early neuroinflammation that is observed in the brain. Thus, our results suggest that targeting Aβ-burdened neurons may be a viable therapeutic strategy for AD.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and that the majority of the bones belong to adult individuals. We further present a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of chicken domestication and its spread in the ancient world. (PsycINFO Database Record

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding protein folding. We have developed a method to study folding at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the maltose binding protein, a 370-residue protein that folds in two distinct steps. The first step is a fast compaction into a polyglobular state that is determined by small-angle X-ray scattering. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is a prerequisite for folding to the native state. The intermediate is adjacent to the first step in the folding pathway. The results suggest that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. The intermediate is a common feature of the folding of several large proteins. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Np4 decapping is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs, potentially affecting bacterial adaptability to stress. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system evolves to a critical state in which the system’s dynamics are self-sustaining. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is a signature of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The antifungal activity of cysteine-rich peptides has been demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the structure of a unique NCR peptide and demonstrate its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides and penetrates the fungal cell wall and membrane. The peptide induces reactive oxygen species and cell death in germlings. The peptide is effective in controlling gray mold disease in tomato and tobacco plants. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the male–female interface in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome immediately after mating and continue to do so for at least 4 d. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the male–female interface and suggest that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a foundation for future studies of the male–female interface and reproductive success. (Simplified version available.)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, with a focus on the largest and most comprehensive case-control studies. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The database is freely available to the scientific community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. The HSRL is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. We use the HSRL to conduct a case study over Beijing, China, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is ∼15 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction is ∼70 °C. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface cooled from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the molecular gates that control ion flow. The K+ channel KCNB1 has two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. However, we found that the BK channel C-type inactivation occurred during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or with decreased intracellular calcium ([Ca2+]i) and recovered with depolarized membrane potentials or elevated [Ca2+]i. This finding suggests that C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help to understand the physiological roles of K+ channel C-type inactivation. (Simplified version available.)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the RBC. We show that the parasite binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and that this interaction leads to a number of changes in the RBC biophysical properties. These changes in turn reduce a critical energy barrier to invasion. This work provides a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work also provides a number of potential targets for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Contains figures and tables.)

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza-associated respiratory disease. This may have important implications for the development of influenza vaccines

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. But how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s neural activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may help to explain the brain’s ability to understand and produce complex sentences.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a key component of the pathway that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work may help to understand the evolution of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra (SN), which project to LH. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, peri-LH neurons, or neurons in the VTA. Finally, we found that peri-LH neurons are necessary for the effect, as was demonstrated by stimulation of peri-LH neurons in the lateral hypothalamus. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the small number of participating communities. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuel use can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year worldwide and 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. This is equivalent to a reduction of 10–70% in the number of deaths from air pollution. The reduction of aerosols liberates rainfall over large parts of the world, and the reduction of air pollution can moderate the warming from methane and ozone. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The ligand–receptor interaction between secreted small ALKAL proteins and ALK family receptors is implicated in the development of several human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK are activated by zebrafish ALKALs. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the ligand–receptor interaction between ALKALs and ALK family receptors in neural crest development and suggest a role of ALKALs in neuroblastoma tumorigenesis. The emergence of plague from its progenitor, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, is a well-documented event in the history of infectious disease. However, the timing and geographic spread of this process are poorly understood. We present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution and ecology of plague during this critical period. Our results suggest a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Simplified version available.)

This work examined the extent to which men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, SOC sequestration in agricultural systems is often limited by the loss of soil organic matter (SOM) to the soil-borne mineral phase. This study demonstrates that soil health management practices can increase SOM storage in agricultural systems. We found that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can increase SOM storage on agricultural soils. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and highlight the importance of including perennial pastures in agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and spread and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. The database is publicly available at spillover.org. This work provides a framework for systematically identifying and prioritizing viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the reward’s nutritional value, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of nectar color in plants. (Read more)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of this panel of individuals indicates that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that women with artificial skull deformations had ancestry from southeastern Europe. Finally, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and MERS coronavirus are different. The receptor usage of HKU4 is opposite to that of MERS coronavirus. The cell entry activity of HKU4 is similar to that of MERS coronavirus. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated by two DNA polymerases, pol δ and pol ε. Pol δ is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and anchors to the PCNA sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Most of our understanding comes from Saccharomyces cerevisae where the extreme stability of the pol δ holoenzyme ensures that every nucleobase within an Okazaki fragment is faithfully duplicated before dissociation but also necessitates an active displacement mechanism for polymerase recycling and exchange. However, the human pol δ holoenzyme is remarkably stable. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This behavior is unique to human DNA polymerases and may be a key to understanding the evolution of the human genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can now replicate RNA molecules, but the fidelity of this process is limited. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that improved the fidelity of the polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase ribozyme can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are more diverse and that are more attractive to young adults. These results have implications for urban planning and for the study of urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but excess copper is toxic to cells. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind copper and impact cellular copper content. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is also responsible for copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xanthocillins. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. The discovery of copper-binding fungal natural products may lead to the development of novel antifungal agents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is the first detection of this polymorph in a sedimentary environment. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and possibly detrital high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT. The amorphous silica is precipitated from variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities of aqueous solutions. The post-lithification fracture/vein fill of anhydrite is consistent with the presence of aqueous fluids in the sediment source region and/or at the site of sediment compaction. The sedimentary mudstone and its cogenetic minerals are a potential source for the silica-rich material in the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific and that these strategies can be used to forecast the future vulnerability of forests to frost damage. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are unclear. We found that Th17 cells could contribute to the development of classic Th1 cells and that the development of colitis required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for treating inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical phenotypes. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the spinal cord, the site of motor neuron culture, after death. We now report a method to produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We now demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its transmission. We show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the tick microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan pentapeptide chain, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a tick-borne pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. The findings have implications for the development of strategies to control tick-borne diseases. (Simplified version available.) The origin of the avian tail and its function are among the most fundamental questions in avian evolution. The discovery of Jinguofortis perplexus provides new insights into the evolution of the avian tail. The fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals is a primitive feature in birds and may have been formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. We also describe a new mechanism for color change, which is based on the binding of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. This mechanism is used by anurans, a group of frogs and toads, to change their color from green to blue-green. This is the first time that this mechanism has been described in vertebrates. Our results provide new insights into the evolution of color change in vertebrates and may have implications for other aspects of vertebrate biology.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates m6A in NANOG mRNA, which encodes a breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) marker. ALKBH5 expression is increased in BCSCs and hypoxia induces ALKBH5 expression in a HIF-dependent manner. ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs and decreases the number of BCSCs in a NANOG-dependent manner. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes BCSC expansion. These findings provide a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in breast cancer progression. They also suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for breast cancer treatment. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that ALKBH5 expression is decreased in breast cancer patients with breast cancer. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a useful biomarker for breast cancer prognosis and treatment.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study uses a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe biotic event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the recovery of ecosystems. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 My, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the first 500 ka of the extinction, and ecosystem recovery was protracted. The age model presented here will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses for the extinction. (Read more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence of the most common mutation (D614G) with the wild-type protein. We find that the mutant spike is in a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation.
