The chemical properties of atoms are essential to understand the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Climate change is driving changes in fire regimes, but the effects are uncertain. We quantify the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions, and we show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, but with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand and mitigate its effects.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning strategy may be a general mechanism used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. Understanding the mechanisms by which animals regulate the activities of their symbionts may provide new insights into the evolution of symbiosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as discourse atoms. Each atom is a distribution over words. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives. Many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is particularly useful for identifying latent patterns in text data that are not captured by existing structured variables. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method can be extended to other domains and other types of text data. It can also be used to identify latent patterns in other types of data.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30–50% of Europe’s population, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease originated in Asia and spread to Europe via the ancient Silk Road. We show that the climate in Asia and Europe was in a state of transition during the 14th century, which may have facilitated the reintroduction of plague into Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 y between each introduction.

The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting a large number of species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of SSWD. We provide evidence that the virus is transmitted by the sea star kinadiid, which is a common predator of asteroids. The virus is also found in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it is spread by the food web. The virus has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y, suggesting that it may have been present in the region for a much longer time. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality of asteroids. The discovery of a densovirus as the cause of a mass mortality event in the sea stars is a significant finding.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The majority of AML patients express the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP), which is a target for antibody-based therapy. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island with a rich cultural and genetic heritage. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and found a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a recent settlement of Madagascar, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar and its impact on the present genomic diversity. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress genes involved in carbon utilization. The RNA and protein compete for the same cellular resources, and the RNA is able to compensate for the protein’s interference with gene repression. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased, and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought has increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive information. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the extent to which people react more strongly to negative information varies considerably across individuals. This work thus helps account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. It also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of disease pathology. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of Htt aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. The earliest known aquatic angiosperms are poorly known and poorly understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Simplified version available.)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we use satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y. We find that the observed acceleration is consistent with the quadratic component of the IPCC AR5 climate model projections. This study provides a more precise estimate of the climate-change–driven sea level acceleration than previous studies. The results also provide a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise than previous studies.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in midlife for all Americans, but that pain has increased more rapidly in the youngest birth cohorts than in the oldest birth cohorts. This pattern is seen across education levels, but is most pronounced for those with less education. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we tested the efficacy of prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major influence on this system. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. This represents a substantial contribution to the global environmental challenge from a relatively simple change in catering practice. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on population health and the environment.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of breast epithelial cells stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 30 million confirmed cases and over 650,000 deaths worldwide. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis for the severity of the COVID-19 disease. This work also provides a foundation for the development of antiviral therapeutics and vaccines. Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of birds and humans. They cause annual epidemics and occasionally severe pandemics. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies in the United States from 1992 to 2012. We find that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of cities.

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and income for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the only known regenerative capacity is in the peripheral nervous system. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the MAPK signaling cascade. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the adult CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. In humans and mice, hotspots are largely defined by binding sites of the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that hotspots are also interspersed among cold regions. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and may be relevant to the evolution of recombination in other organisms.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interconnected networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the brain’s functional organization. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We observed that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is a major determinant of mRNA stability and translation efficiency. We report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in yeast, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap is found on pre-mRNAs and is not associated with the final 5′ monophosphate. The 5′ NAD+ cap may be a new posttranscriptional modification that regulates mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences at certain loci persist during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and EDIC Study and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to confirm these findings and to determine whether DNA-me alterations at these loci are causal in the maintenance of metabolic memory. (Epigenetics 2014; 8: 123–132.)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study suggests that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence. The gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Tomato fruit are a major source of flavor in the human diet. The biosynthesis of the volatile nitrogen-containing compounds that contribute to the fruit aroma is not known. Using an introgression population, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This locus encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This pathway is unique to tomato and likely contributes to the fruit’s distinctive aroma. Understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor compounds will be essential for improving fruit quality. (Simplified version available.)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem functioning and biodiversity loss is expected to increase temperatures. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but the anatomical and functional organization of its neurons is unknown. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from MEC neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for navigation in place, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. This suggests that grid cells might form a distinct network. Our data also suggest that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker connections to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and their functional roles in spatial navigation. They may also be relevant to other navigational tasks, such as learning the layout of indoor environments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of both host and parasite. This study illustrates how flowering regulation may have evolved in plants and how flowering may be synchronized in host–parasite interactions.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is a critical component of the brain’s reward and movement control circuitry. We show that the striatonigral fibers that innervate the striatum form bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of dopamine-containing dendrites and their parent cell bodies in the ventral tegmental area. These dendron clusters likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given the role of striosomes in mood and motivation, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a unique view of the brain’s dopamine-containing nigral system and its connections to the striatum. It also provides a model for the formation of other types of specialized integrative units in the brain. This model could be applied to other systems in the brain and to other types of cells and fibers. The model could also be used to study the formation of other specialized integrative units in the brain. We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are composed of specialized cardiomyocytes that are unique in their electrophysiological properties. The SAN is a small organelle that is difficult to study in vivo. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and is required for their automaticity. STIM1 regulates the Ca2+ content of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) and the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to the SAN’s automaticity. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN function. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have been less well studied. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type rice plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonic acid biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and jasmonic acid is likely mediated by priming of jasmonic acid-mediated defense responses. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice against insect herbivory. This study also provides a framework for the use of Si as a biopesticide in other crops. Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor synthesized from GTP. It is essential for nitric oxide synthesis and aromatic amino acid hydroxylation. It is also used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about its role in lipid metabolism. Here we found tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase to be essential for ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We also found that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a link between tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid metabolism and opens new perspectives for the development of new therapeutic strategies for ether lipid-related diseases. Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that it can support the binding of linguistic features over time, which is a key feature of language processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures into plant cells and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a foundation for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is a major driver of coastal eutrophication in large lakes. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely ignored. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of coastal nutrients, especially in areas where dams have altered the natural hydrology of the watershed. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these overlooked sources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. We also find that the network’s dynamics are sensitive to the environmental forcing, and that the system can exhibit a rich variety of dynamical behaviors, including chaotic dynamics. These results suggest that the environmental forcing may play a more important role in the dynamics of chemical networks than previously appreciated.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoantibodies that cause autoimmune encephalitis. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, which can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. This work may help to develop new therapeutic strategies for patients with NMDAR-Abs. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. We present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results highlight the potential for the Earth system to respond to rapid warming with a release of organic matter–derived carbon and nutrient fluxes. This could have important implications for the future of the biosphere and the climate.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved in plants and animals. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of vacuolar trafficking. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be increased by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. (Simplified version available.)

The retina is challenged by oxidative stress from the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) and photogenerated reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key regulator of bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Fe in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for retinal diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the foundation of most food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to limit the evolution of new prey types. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, can evolve into new prey types without losing their specialization. This finding suggests that specialization is not a dead end, and that morphological evolution can lead to new prey types. Our results contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the modern human hand is a key topic in human evolutionary biology. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from 1.42 Mya that shows a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The discovery of this fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that the evolution of the modern human hand was driven by ecological and behavioral changes associated with the transition from Africa to Eurasia. Cancer cells have a number of metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited to treat cancer. One such vulnerability is the one-carbon unit, which is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in this metabolic pathway. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. This work provides a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited to treat cancer. This study provides evidence that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output and more food to be produced. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
